title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Upozornění



This course material is currently under construction and is likely incomplete. The final version will be released in October 2023.
This will be a course on Spatial Data Science for Social Geography.
The course will be taught in person at Charles University in Prague from October 2023.
More information will be shared closer to the starting date.

title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Aims
TBD






Is it only for social geography?



The course revolves around data typically used in social geography but its applicability is by no means limited to social geography. In practice, you will work more with vector data than rasters (although we cover those a bit as well) and often with data capturing various aspects of human life. The spatial data science concepts, however, are universal.

title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Learning outcomes
After finishing the course, students will be able to:

TBD

title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Prerequisites
This course assumes an understanding of geography and its key concepts (e.g. coordinate reference systems or the Modifiable Areal Unit Problem (Openshaw 1983)), at least basic familiarity with GIS (like file formats and basic spatial data manipulation) and a basic understanding of statistics (e.g. understanding the concept of regression), optimally with some spatial component (geographically weighted regression). While the course will briefly explain these topics, it will not cover the theory and statistics behind these concepts in detail.
No prior experience with programming or computer science is needed, although a positive attitude towards these topics is necessary.

title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Course structure
The material is planned for 12 weeks with one session per week. Each session is divided into three parts - Concepts, Hands-on and Exercise, following the model proposed by Arribas-Bel (2019). Concepts have a form of a lecture covering conceptual aspects of the topic of the day, providing necessary theoretical background before digging into code. This part can be nicknamed “I do”. Hands-on contains documented code in a form of a Jupyter notebook which is executed in parallel by a lecturer, providing an additional explanation, and by students. Therefore, we have a part “We do”. Exercise is a set of tasks that are to be performed by students individually, with an occasional guidance by the lecturer. So we finish the day with “You do”.
For enrolled students of Charles University, the course will finish with a written assignment in a form of a computational essay. See the Assignment section for details.

title: Spatial Data Science for Social Geography
text:
Literature
The course loosely follows the contents of the Geographic Data Science with Python by Rey, Arribas-Bel, a Wolf (2023). The online version of the book is available under open access from geographicdata.science/book. It is recommended to use the online version over the printed one, although this is entirely up to you.

title: Graph here, graph there
text:
Exercise on creation and transformation of weights. Make them understand what is the structure and how to work with it.
Inlcude lags.

title: Spatial weights in PySAL
text:
libpysal and creation of various kinds of weights matrices and operations on them.
spatial lag and its relationship to weight value and transformation method.

Need to figure out if I should teach current W or the new one from the experimental namespace. Probably will have to stick to the current one as the rest of PySAL might not work with the new one by October. Let’s check with the PySAL team. Would be awesome to teach the new class.
